segments.text: This is an interview with Lieutenant General James Hollingsworth up at Hearst, Texas.
Today is Wednesday, the 18th of August, 1982.
The first thing I'd like to ask you to do is donate.
Would you please donate this tape and all the information on this tape to Texas A&M University?
I'd be happy to do that.
Okay, now let's start right now with your early years.
You were born here in Texas.
Could you tell me about your parents?
Yes, sir.
I was born on the 24th of March, 1918.
the first son of James Newton Hollingsworth and Mamie Ella Hollingsworth.
They were the sole owners of a small ranch and farm seven miles north and west of Sanger, Texas.
property was in located in Denton and Cook County crossing the borders between the two counties in the Union Hill community area I uh
Went to school some one mile away to the Union Hill School, which consists of three teachers and three rooms.
Through the eighth grade, I walked to school.
rain or shine or mud or snow or whatever it might be.
In those days you carried your lunch in a small pail and the lunch was usually made up of the leftovers from breakfast.
Which could very well be two biscuits and two pieces of sausage.
Or a light few pieces of bacon and biscuits.
Was your father a farmer, though?
My father was a farmer.
and the hardest working man I've ever met in my life.
Tell me more about him.
What kind of character was he?
He was a very strong-charactered man, a very disciplined man.
He had moved from Alabama to Texas with his parents when he was about age
ten and uh his father paid cash for this three hundred acres of land and uh my fathers my grandfather and his my grandmother
raised one daughter and seven sons, of which my father was the oldest.
He was a very strong man, a self-educated man, had been through the third grade formal schooling, and had read everything that he could get his hands on.
and I shall always remember they subscribed.
My mother had, my father was 44 years old when I was born, and my mother was much younger, 20 years or more younger than my father.
And he was a disciplinarian in the sense that not,
As most civilians understand discipline, you know, in civilian side of life, most civilians treat discipline as a punishment.
Well, discipline isn't a punishment.
Discipline is the art of learning, learning to do things well.
And in that extent, he was a disciplinarian because he insisted that the children learn to do things well.
and honesty and integrity and to stand up for what you believe in.
And that's the kind of a man he was.
How about your mother?
My mother was a wonderful woman who, as I say, much younger than my father, who was out of a Scottish family.
of Browning's.
Her father and mother were more or less sharecroppers.
Since my father was a landowner, I think that I could see a little resentment at times to the basic philosophy of my mother's father and mother.
to his.

For example, I've heard him say at times that socialism is the worst thing in the world and that free enterprise and ownership and I guess the thing that he hated worst was to have to borrow money in order maybe to put in a
part of a crop or to buy a piece of equipment or something like that.
He hated that worse than anything.
He was one who felt like that if you don't have the money to pay for it, that doesn't represent true ownership.
So, he and of course my mother were just worked themselves to death, so to speak.
I remember that from the time I was six years old.

But I could always, when I was a little larger, I could detect that sensitivity to his feelings toward, and he never made any derogatory remarks about my mother's family being sharecroppers because they had a large family too, 12 or 13.
children, and they all married well.
Some married preachers, some married farmers, some married day laborers and this sort of stuff.
But my mom was just a magnificent person that did everything and worked so hard doing everything, you know, on the farm, cooking.
Some days she'd go to the fields with us.
when I was large enough to go to the field and work, particularly during the harvest, the grain, the cotton, the corn.
I suppose when I was seven years old, I was walking a mile to the north of our pasture land through the fields in order to drive in the herd of cattle for the evening when I was seven years old.
So, I started pretty young.

By the time I was ten years old, I had the responsibility of from twenty-five to thirty black workers during the harvest all during the summer from the time school was out in May until we started back to school in September.
I began responsibilities for supervising and managing those.
My father turned that over to me.
at ten, at age ten.
So he gave you quite a bit of responsibility as a young man.
Yes, and he taught me a lot about how to deal with people.

He said you have to learn to treat them all alike, and I remember one of the first questions I asked him about that was, I said, well, Dad, I've learned here this year that these people are all different.
Now, how can you treat them all alike?
Different in what way did you mean?
Well, I said they think differently.
They don't look the same.
They act differently.
One will try to cheat you weighing cotton, and one is so honest that he may be the other way around.
I said some of them are strong, some of them are weak, some of them eat more than the others.
Some of them are...
are smarter than the others.
I said, they're all different, and you want me to treat them all alike?
He said, I want you to treat them all alike from the standpoint of fairness and justice.
And so that bothered me for about 25 years.
Treat them all alike when they're all different.
And that, at age 10, is when I started my study of people, because here was a wagon or a tractor.
The personality of that tractor, of all the three or four tractors we had out there, was all the same.
But the personality of those people out there were all different.
And this is where I think you have to understand that this had a real impact on me back in those days.
And I go back and think about it for the simple reason that I knew nothing about it.
I didn't even know what the word leadership meant.
Back in those days, we knew
The term is a foreman, or a foreman for this, not the other.
Foreman.
So, ten years old, my father entrusted me as a foreman to move these people.
When I was ten years old, I took a wagon, two mules, bedding roll,
I spent the night on Red River.
Next day I got into Ardmore and helped move these transits down to work all summer.
In the fall, my father would take them back because I would be in school at that time.
How'd you get along with the black people?
I got along with them very well.
I learned from one old gentleman named Jim Sutton, S-U-T-T-O-N, who was an old timer that lived with us.
He and his wife, Virge, lived on our place all the time, constantly.
There were permanent pictures there.
I learned a lot from him about black people.
You do learn a lot with them if you eat breakfast with them, or they eat with you at the house, and they're working with you all day and all night.
You learn a lot about them, about association, and you.
You got that, and you know they're,
They're just like we are.
They eat, they sleep, they work, wear the same kind of clothes.
They've got a heart, a mind, and a soul.
And I learned then that there's no difference between them and us.
Well, with your experience as a young man with the blacks and
later on when there was a civil rights movement in this country.
Did you support that or were you basically against it or what were your feelings toward that based on your early years?
I felt that we, the whites, that we the blacks had suffered a hundred years of injustice.
That's the way I felt.
A hundred years of injustice.
And I feel that way today.
Now, some of the catch-up things that we've done, I don't necessarily approve of, but I can understand them happening.
Some of the specific programs, you think, weren't very wise.
Weren't very wise at all.
As a matter of fact, I think you've jeopardized and made
many of the blacks are shameful of what's happening, and I think this is very bad.
In general, then, you support it?
Oh, 100 percent, absolutely, absolutely.
And I feel the same way about the other minorities, the Mexican-Americans, the same way.
I think that
that we oftentimes go overboard in trying to play a game of catch-up.
In other words, if somebody wants to be a millionaire, you don't do that overnight.
But I support fairness and justice for all, and the color of your skin
in my view, has nothing to do with what's in your heart, mind, and soul.
Okay.
I'll let you continue with your mother.
You started in telling me a little bit about your mother, but you never described her.
You never told me about her character.
My mother was aif you could describe my mother and if she had had the opportunity, she would have probably been one of the greatest pianists in this country.
Really?
Yes.
And she had a wonderful voice, not unlike her other brothers and sisters who had wonderful voices.
They were a church singing type.
I've never heard my mother sing many songs other than those which
or were of religious nature.
She attempted to teach myself and my three younger brothers to play the piano.
And because of interest outside the house, somewhere on the farm or the ranch,
This indoor sports and activities weren't to our liking, other than reading.
I did a tremendous amount of reading about kerosene light and then the gas light.
What kind of books did you usually read?
I read history books.
I read all the magazines on current affairs that we could get.
We had an old magazine, I don't believe it's around anymore, Literary Digest.
Got Saturday Evening Post, those types of things that I think we must have subscribed to.
generally speaking, most all the major magazines at that time.
You mentioned singing in church.
Was your family religious?
Yes, very religious, particularly my mother.
What church did you go to?
She was a Baptist, and I make no bones about the fact that
I joined that church.
It was in the schoolhouse, but I found good reason to get rid of that as soon as I could.
It was very distasteful for me, even at age eight, nine, or ten, to know that on Saturday night my father and I had bottled up

some home brew and put it in the cellar and be in church the next day and the preacher tell me that anybody that drank beer or anybody that smoked or anything like that was going to go to hell when I knew damn well at that age that wasn't the case so that was very distasteful to me and I thought well
given an opportunity, I'm going to have to listen to this the rest of my life.
And I didn't.

When I was at West Point as an instructor, Ms. Hollingsworth and our son, we joined the Episcopalian, either Episcopalian or Lutheran, so we joined the Episcopalian Church in England, which we were very fond of and still active in.
But, uh Was your father religious?

My father belonged to the Baptist Church, and if he wasn't working on Sunday or there wasn't something, it was just... You see out on the farm and ranch, that's seven days, 24 hours a day, and you don't go anywhere.
Maybe you'd go away for a couple of hours on Sunday afternoon.
You had to get back because you had cattle to feed in the evening.

Maybe we'd all get in the, I never will forget, the first car that I remember having was a big four-door Oldsmobile touring car, you know, with a big top on it, four-door, with side curtains and a cloth top.
I never will forget looking out at the breakfast room
over the kitchen sink one day and a goat had gotten up on the car and fell through the top.
Had his legs hanging down through there.
But it was a funny looking thing.
Unfortunately, the goat belonged to me and my mother took a damn view of it.
But anyway, there was just no time.
So sometimes
The seven-day Adventist worked on Sunday.
There's a number of German farmers and ranchers in our area, and they worked on Sunday.
And oftentimes, my father had something he had to do on Sunday, but he believed in the year after and went to church as much as possible, but not like my mother because she was participating in
in the choir and also playing the piano, so she had to be there.
Was your father ever a leader in the community?
Not to my knowledge, no.
No.
He voted in all elections.
He spent his whole life working out there on that farm.
What political party?
Was he a member of a political party?
Democrats.
He was a Democrat.
Well, would you consider him a liberal, moderate, or conservative?
He was the most conservative that you've ever seen.
He really was.
And what would youdid some of his political views wipe off on you?
Yeah, and I changed the brand from Democrat to Republican.
When did you do that?
As soon as I could, when it become that.
After you moved away from home?
After I moved away from home, yeah.
Probably after you left Texas?
After I left Texas in the military.
Who is the authority in the household?
My father.
You become a three-star general.
In what way do you, what values do you contribute to your parents for your success?
The early placing of responsibility and my willingness to accept the responsibility and meet my father's standards of discipline and doing everything right.
And at the same time,
going above and beyond what you learned in the school and knowing enough and beginning to learn enough about things other than what you see each day and what you learn in school each day.
But I think they
the trust and the early placing of responsibility and accepting responsibility, I learned that in order to get the job done out there and to work with

the men that my father had entrusted to me, some of them were women, that I didn't know what I was doing, but I knew that, yeah, I would like to take off and go fishing, or I'd like to go over here and lay down while they're out doing something else and sleep for 30 minutes before they come back, or I'd like to go to the house and get some ice water
instead of drinking this warm water out of this jug here that's got a cloth sack around it to try to keep it going.
And I could have done that, but I didn't do that.
I decided that I'd drink the same water that they're drinking and out of the same jug.
As I look back on that, I found out what I was doing.
I didn't know at the time.
But I was divesting myself of selfish interests.
In order to deal with people fairly and squarely and justly,
You can't ask them to do something that you won't do yourself.
You can't ask them to drink that warm water out of that jug there, and you go to the house and drink some cold water with some ice in it.
You've got to drink the same thing.
So what I'm saying is, I guess, that don't ever ask people to do it.

do something that you're not willing to do yourself and if need be prove that then you'll begin to lead people to do things and so uh if you want to get involved with people you gotta divest yourself of selfish interest and I guess uh
over the years of my life, that's the thing that I see as a fault amongst most of our people.
I think we're all- Just Americans.
Right, Americans.
Okay, you're talking about Americans in general.
I'm talking about Americans in general.
Okay, good.
Yes, Americans in general.
failure to divest themselves of their own personal selfish interests which I in my study of people I believe is an inherent inborn characteristic of selfishness.
One I do also know is inherent in our American people and that's adventurism.
They're born with adventure.
You can see that in the
in a six-month-old and study of people.
You can see a six-month-old begin to crawl.
Why does he do that?
He's looking for something.
He wants to do something.
He's looking for something.
And you can watch him pull up on the coffee table.
That's adventure.
That's challenge.
Adventure, challenge,
and selfishness, I truly believe in a healthy youth of America is an inborn inherited characteristic.
And I think you can see that displayed in the six months old and on up.
And he pulls up on the coffee table and what attracts him most
the brightest, the most uncommon thing that he's seen around the place.
It might be a red glass ball or whatever it is.
Venture or whatever it is.
So, I've watched this thing for a long, long time.
Let's talk about your education.
What were your favorite subjects?
You mentioned before history books and literature.
Did you like that the most?
I liked chemistry.
Chemistry.
I liked chemistry.
I liked the hands-on things.
I was a very poor student, a very good student, I think, in high school.
The most attractive thing to me was-
learning to do Future Farmer of America projects.

As a matter of fact, I won several awards down at Texas A&M as a high school student in future farmer projects that you have, soldering and welding and cement mixing and sawing and all that sort of vocational sort of thing.
I liked that.
So I inclined toward that sort of thing, engineering.
And so you were a member of the Future Farmers of America.
Oh, yes.
Did you have any roles of leadership when you were?
Oh, yes.
So you started your career as a leader quite young.
Yes, exactly right.
And where was that?
I was in Sanger, Texas after I had left the
Eighth grade, as I say, I lived seven miles away from a community called Sanger.
That was the post office.
That was the high school area.
That was where you bought all your food and that sort of stuff.
And I made that seven miles every day either by horseback or walked.
Remember, that's 14 miles a day.

Now, to play football, in addition, and you get through football practice at 5 o'clock, and you get home and then you drop your books and you go to work feeding cattle and so on and so forth, so you finish that off at 9 o'clock when you study.
You don't.
So you've got to be awful observant.
in the class if you want to get by.
So I did very well.
I had a few problems in English because that was kind of a foreign thing to my interest.
And I followed through at A&M.
You said though that you were a leader in the Future Farmers.
Yes.
And what positions did you have?
I started out as secretary of the Future Farmers my first year, I think, in the ninth grade.
In the tenth grade, I was a vice president, and I was president of the Future Farmers chapter there in Sanger.
I was responsible for help organizing these little fellas and selecting along with Professor Samuel, Professor Eli Samuel.
He's dead now, but he's a magnificent man.
And he was the sort of fella that'd give me responsibilities.

He allowed me to take his car, for example, and take five or six of the key Future Farmers of America from Sanger, all of which is 50 miles north of here, all the way down to Texas A&M, meet him down there.
He'd drive somebody else's car.
He'd give me that responsibility.
He was a professor at A&M.
He was a later professor at A&M.
He was a professor there and the superintendent of the school, a singer.
So he was an influential fellow in my life.
And it's that sort of thing that brought this on.
Did you consider yourself popular in high school?
Were you popular with the other students?
Yes, I think so.
I don't know of any enemies I had.
Sometimes you have some, you don't know it, you know, but most of the time you know who they are.
But as far as I know, I had none.
When you graduated from high school, did you have firm aims about what you wanted to do?
I mean, had you made up your mind, I want to go to A&M or?
Did you think maybe military academy or just what did you think when you graduated?
Well, my dad wanted me to be a doctor of veterinary medicine.
And we had no money for me to go to school on.
Zero.
We never lacked for food or clothing or anything like that.
And didn't have any debts.

But when you make a bumper crop of oats or wheat and you sell it at the end of the year at the harvest time and it just barely pays the fuel bill and doesn't even pay you for your labor and so on and so forth, how can you send a guy that takes his A&M even if it's only for $5 a year?
How do you do it?
Well, I'll tell you how you do it.
Mr. Samuel, Professor Samuel is interested enough in your capabilities and what he sees in you that he assists you in getting a job.
I went to North Texas Agricultural College out here for one year and got off a few credits, but I worked the whole time I was there.
Then I wanted to go to A&M.
So this was kind of a prep school up here.
I worked most of the time.
And then Mr. Samuels helped me get a job at Texas A&M in the creamery down there across the tracks.
And I had done real well in freshman chemistry.
like that sort of stuff.
And first thing you knew, I became the lab technician there.
Well, what does that encompass?
That encompass getting up at four o'clock in the morning and start sampling milk coming into that plant down there from all over Brazos County and so forth.
Sampling that milk

and then going and running the chemical analysis tests on it and then getting that out promptly and giving it to the farmer who's standing by as to what his bacterial count was or whatever the fat content was usually the fat content I run the bacterial count a little later because you know you had to cultivate that a little bit and uh but he has to know what

what the butterfat content is because that's what you're going to pay him per hundred weight on and I had to do that while he was while his truck was waiting and get that on a piece of paper and our and they finally all got in about uh uh 7 45 then I had to run take a shower and made an 8 10 class and then in the afternoon uh
It was four o'clock after school.
We finished up about 830.
That's how much I had to work in order to stay down there.
I think we got 20 cents an hour or something.
I'm not sure what it was.
So you usually put in about eight hours a day.

I worked eight hours a day and tried to take 16 credits and I'd bust the hell out of English and do well on the other subjects and when I finished off down there I lacked one or two grade points of being able to go up and get my diploma and so they deferred my
my diploma for one year because I was short a couple of grade points, but that didn't bother me a damn bit.
They couldn't treat me harshly because I'd learned a hell of a lot.
It was a great hardship, and I'd learned the preciseness that my father had taught me was not in the
subjects and the manner in which the professors had puttin' it across, but was in the hardships that I'd suffered in order to stay in down there, and the military.
Did they send you your diploma the next year, then?
Yes.
Yes.
They sent me my diploma the next year.
That's all right.
I don't mind that.
No.
Hellfire.
Did you ever think about going or applying for West Point?
I guess that that was so far away, and for a farm guy to do that, that was just beyond my capabilities at that time to even apply.
I was happy, though, when West Point selected me as the first non-West Point graduate to go back there as an instructor.
Did the fact that we had a Corps of Cadets have anything to do with your deciding to go to A&M?
Yes, it did.
Will you explain?
I was here at
NTHC, they had North Texas Agricultural College.
You could either join the ROTC or not.
And I watched, I watched for about a week these fellows all in the same uniform and
They were doing things together, and they had a leader out there, and they had junior leaders.
I said to myself, that's the sort of thing that would really be nice if I could progress up to be a leader of those guys there.
I haven't seen anything else around here that's demanding from the standpoint of somebody being in charge and people reacting.
And I knew they had a big corps of cadets at Texas A&M, and I thought the bigger the cadet corps, the better chance you've got of progressing up to some leadership.
And I think that's what inspired me more to go to A&M.
So it was a combination of the military and the desire to be a veterinarian?
Yes, and my father was pushing me on the veterinarian business, but when I got out of A&M, I looked at this business of five years and studying, and there was just no way that I could
stay in school down there and work, and ever become a doctor of veterinary medicine.
I mean, the requirements are very demanding, and you've got to be able to put forth time to study.
And, hell, when did I study?
When do you study if you're working seven or eight hours a day?
When do you do that?
Let me tell you what you've got to do.
You've got to somehow or another, regardless of how little sleep and how tired you are, you've got to stay awake.
in class and listen and make notes on everything and be able to read the notes after you make them.
That's what you've got to do.
And you've got to have a book and you've got to, when somebody else wants to go out and play some softball or something,
Whenever it is you've got some free time, you've got to thumb through those books and inspect these things and pick out what you think is important.
And sometimes you miss.
